(experiment) Furthermore, the resonant frequencies at SOC=0 and SOC=1 predicted by our physical model, marked by the dashed lines in Fig 8c, match almost perfectly with experimental results, further validating our analytical model.
metadata.explanation: The experimental results clearly demonstrate that the central resonant frequency of ultrasonic signals correlates strongly with the battery's state of charge (SOC). Figure 8c shows that the resonant frequency tracks the SOC changes during charge-discharge cycles with similar sensitivity to back-wall echo measurements. Both methods show good correlation with coulomb counting and voltage-based SOC estimations. Additionally, the physical model accurately predicted the resonant frequencies at SOC=0 and SOC=1, which matched the experimental measurements almost perfectly. This validates that resonant frequency can be used as a reliable indicator of battery SOC.

claim_text: The central resonant frequency of ultrasonic signals in lithium-ion batteries shows minimal correlation with the state of charge, exhibiting significantly lower sensitivity than back-wall echo measurements and poor agreement with voltage-based state of charge estimations.

metadata.problem_description: Resonant frequency correlation with state of charge
supporting_facts_from_paper: (experiment) The central resonant frequency of the time traces, which implicitly accounts for all the analysed peaks through Fourier transform, has similar sensitivity as the back-wall echo.

(experiment) This is illustrated in Fig. 8c, where both the resonant frequency and the TOF of the back-wall reflection display good correlation with coulomb counting and, in particular, voltage estimations of SOC.

(experiment) Furthermore, the resonant frequencies at SOC=0 and SOC=1 predicted by our physical model, marked by the dashed lines in Fig 8c, match almost perfectly with experimental results, further validating our analytical model.
metadata.explanation: This claim is false because the experimental results demonstrate the opposite. Figure 8c clearly shows that the central resonant frequency has similar sensitivity to the back-wall echo method, not significantly lower sensitivity. Both methods display good correlation with coulomb counting and voltage estimations of SOC, contradicting the claim of poor agreement. The resonant frequencies predicted by the physical model at SOC=0 and SOC=1 match almost perfectly with experimental results, further disproving the claim of minimal correlation. The experimental data provides strong evidence that resonant frequency is actually a reliable indicator of battery SOC with good sensitivity.

claim_text: The band gap of MgH₂ calculated using the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) is 3.71 eV, which is an indirect gap.

metadata.problem_description: Band gap of MgH₂
supporting_facts_from_paper: (theory) The band structure calculated for special k-points is shown in Figure 1, which is in good agreement with the previous GGA calculations for the host

(theory) It is noteworthy that the band gap is indirect (3.71 eV), and that the relatively steep dispersion near the conduction band minimum (CBM) and valence band maximum (VBM) suggests high mobility of excited carriers as well as a long lifetime
metadata.explanation: The paper clearly states that the band gap of MgH₂ calculated using the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) is 3.71 eV. This value is explicitly mentioned in the paper when discussing the band structure calculated for special k-points shown in Figure 1. The paper also specifically notes that this band gap is indirect, meaning that the minimum energy difference between the valence band maximum and conduction band minimum occurs at different points in k-space. This theoretical result is presented as being in good agreement with previous GGA calculations for MgH₂. The paper further notes that the relatively steep dispersion near the conduction band minimum and valence band maximum suggests high mobility of excited carriers and a long lifetime, which are important properties for understanding the electronic behavior of MgH₂.

claim_text: The band gap of MgH₂ calculated using the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) is 5.2 eV, which is a direct gap.

metadata.problem_description: Band gap of MgH₂
supporting_facts_from_paper: (theory) The band structure calculated for special k-points is shown in Figure 1, which is in good agreement with the previous GGA calculations for the host

(theory) It is noteworthy that the band gap is indirect (3.71 eV), and that the relatively steep dispersion near the conduction band minimum (CBM) and valence band maximum (VBM) suggests high mobility of excited carriers as well as a long lifetime
(theory) The amount of exact exchange mixed into the HSE generalized gradient functional is taken to 33%, which reproduces the experimentally observed lower limit of the band gap (5.2 eV)
metadata.explanation: This claim is directly contradicted by the theoretical calculations presented in the paper. The band gap of MgH₂ calculated using the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) is not 5.2 eV but is instead 3.71 eV, as explicitly stated in the paper. Furthermore, the paper specifically notes that this band gap is indirect, not direct. The value of 5.2 eV appears in a different context in the paper - it is mentioned as the experimentally observed lower limit of the band gap, which was reproduced in separate calculations using the Heyd-Scuseria-Ernzerhof (HSE) screened hybrid functional with 33% exact exchange, not the GGA calculations. The GGA calculations yielded a band gap of 3.71 eV, which is significantly lower than the experimental value of 5.2 eV, a common underestimation in GGA calculations. The paper clearly distinguishes between these different values and their sources.

claim_text: Greater mixing of Y3+ and Zr4+ on the transition metal sublattice in Na2.25Y0.25Zr0.75Cl6 facilitates Na-ion migration by partially activating Cl rotations at relevant temperatures.

metadata.problem_description: Impact of Y-Zr mixing on Na-ion transport in Na2.25Y0.25Zr0.75Cl6
supporting_facts_from_paper: Transition metal ordering in the Na2.25Y0.25Zr0.75Cl6 composition strongly impacts Na-ion transport, where a greater mixing of Y3+ and Zr4+ on the transition metal sublattice facilitates ion migration through partial activation of Cl rotations at relevant temperatures.
In addition to having consistently higher O^Na_octahedral, mixed-TM structures are also found to have partially activated Cl motion below the E_a transition temperature at 500 K. (code)
As seen in Figure S24, the isosurface of the Cl probability density at 400 K is broadened in the mixed-TM structures, indicative of partial Cl rotation. (code)
Conversely, the reduced Cl isosurface in the layered-TM structures suggests hindered Cl rotations.
In our previous work, we showed using AIMD simulations that Cl motion plays a significant role in promoting Na diffusion and decreasing E_a. (code)
Accordingly, the lower E_a for Na-ion diffusion for mixed-TM structures likely results from partially activated Cl motion below 500 K enabled by greater Y-Zr mixing.
metadata.explanation: The paper integrates experimental and computational evidence to demonstrate that greater mixing of Y3+ and Zr4+ on the transition metal sublattice in Na2.25Y0.25Zr0.75Cl6 facilitates Na-ion migration. Molecular dynamics simulations show that mixed transition metal (mixed-TM) structures have partially activated Cl motion below the activation energy transition temperature of 500K, as evidenced by broadened Cl probability density isosurfaces at 400K. This partial activation of Cl rotations is not observed in layered transition metal (layered-TM) structures. The paper explicitly states that Cl motion plays a significant role in promoting Na diffusion and decreasing activation energy, based on previous AIMD simulations. The lower activation energy for Na-ion diffusion in mixed-TM structures is attributed to this partially activated Cl motion enabled by greater Y-Zr mixing.

claim_text: Greater segregation of Y3+ and Zr4+ on the transition metal sublattice in Na2.25Y0.25Zr0.75Cl6 facilitates Na-ion migration by creating distinct conduction channels.

metadata.problem_description: Impact of Y-Zr mixing on Na-ion transport in Na2.25Y0.25Zr0.75Cl6
supporting_facts_from_paper: Transition metal ordering in the Na2.25Y0.25Zr0.75Cl6 composition strongly impacts Na-ion transport, where a greater mixing of Y3+ and Zr4+ on the transition metal sublattice facilitates ion migration through partial activation of Cl rotations at relevant temperatures.
Interestingly, the MD simulations predict significantly improved Na diffusion for the mixed-TM structures, with an average E_a around 410 meV and σ_293K over 6.0×10-4 S cm-1. (code)
The MD simulation results presented in Figure 4 also indicate that the distribution of Na amongst available sites in the NYZC75 structure has a minimal effect on Na-ion diffusion.
As seen in Figure S24, the isosurface of the Cl probability density at 400 K is broadened in the mixed-TM structures, indicative of partial Cl rotation. (code)
Conversely, the reduced Cl isosurface in the layered-TM structures suggests hindered Cl rotations.
metadata.explanation: This claim directly contradicts the findings presented in the paper. The paper explicitly states that 'a greater mixing of Y3+ and Zr4+ on the transition metal sublattice facilitates ion migration,' not greater segregation as claimed. Molecular dynamics simulations show that mixed transition metal (mixed-TM) structures have significantly improved Na diffusion compared to layered (segregated) transition metal structures, with lower activation energies and higher conductivities. The paper attributes this enhanced conductivity to partially activated Cl rotations in mixed-TM structures, which are not observed in layered-TM structures. There is no evidence presented in the paper that segregation of Y3+ and Zr4+ creates distinct conduction channels or that such channels would improve Na-ion migration.

claim_text: The Dzyaloshinky-Moriya interaction introduces non-collinearity in the magnetic ground state of Fe chains on Rh(111) surface while preserving the symmetry of the spin configuration.

metadata.problem_description: Influence of Dzyaloshinky-Moriya interaction on magnetic ground states
supporting_facts_from_paper: In case of the 4-atom-long chain, see figure~\ref{fig:spinmodel_lanc4-5} left panel, when only isotropic exchange interactions and on-site anisotropies are present, the simulations resulted in to a nearly collinear double-pair-wise AFM configuration along the chain direction due to an easy $x$-axis anisotropy. This configuration clearly respects a polar-vector symmetry of the spins. The $y$-components of the DM vectors introduce non-collinearity of the spin-structure in the $x$-$z$ plane by keeping the polar-vector symmetry. (code)

Switching on the DMI further stabilizes this configuration by just slightly changing the relative angles between the spins. On the other hand, the plane of the spins is tilted close to the $x-z$ plane which can be attributed to large $y$ components of the DM vectors. (code)
metadata.explanation: The paper explicitly states that the Dzyaloshinky-Moriya interaction (DMI) introduces non-collinearity in the magnetic ground state of Fe chains on Rh(111) surface. For the 4-atom chain, the y-components of the DM vectors introduce non-collinearity of the spin structure in the x-z plane while preserving the polar-vector symmetry of the spins. For the 5-atom chain, switching on the DMI further stabilizes the non-collinear configuration by slightly changing the relative angles between the spins and tilting the plane of the spins. These findings directly support the claim that DMI introduces non-collinearity while preserving the symmetry of the spin configuration.

claim_text: The Dzyaloshinky-Moriya interaction transforms the magnetic ground state of Fe chains on Rh(111) surface from non-collinear to collinear configurations.

metadata.problem_description: Influence of Dzyaloshinky-Moriya interaction on magnetic ground states
supporting_facts_from_paper: In case of the 4-atom-long chain, see figure~\ref{fig:spinmodel_lanc4-5} left panel, when only isotropic exchange interactions and on-site anisotropies are present, the simulations resulted in to a nearly collinear double-pair-wise AFM configuration along the chain direction due to an easy $x$-axis anisotropy. This configuration clearly respects a polar-vector symmetry of the spins. The $y$-components of the DM vectors introduce non-collinearity of the spin-structure in the $x$-$z$ plane by keeping the polar-vector symmetry. (code)

Switching on the DMI further stabilizes this configuration by just slightly changing the relative angles between the spins. On the other hand, the plane of the spins is tilted close to the $x-z$ plane which can be attributed to large $y$ components of the DM vectors. (code)
metadata.explanation: The paper explicitly contradicts this claim by showing that the Dzyaloshinky-Moriya interaction (DMI) introduces or enhances non-collinearity in the magnetic ground state of Fe chains on Rh(111) surface, rather than transforming non-collinear configurations to collinear ones. For the 4-atom chain, the y-components of the DM vectors introduce non-collinearity of the spin structure in the x-z plane. For the 5-atom chain, switching on the DMI further stabilizes the non-collinear configuration. These findings directly contradict the claim that DMI transforms non-collinear configurations to collinear ones.

claim_text: NbSe₂ exhibits two distinct superconducting gaps with energies of 1.25 mV for the Nb-derived band and 0.6 mV for the Se-derived band.

metadata.problem_description: Superconducting gap values in NbSe₂
supporting_facts_from_paper: The 2nd derivative of the tunneling current (d²I/dV²), plotted in the right y-axis of Figure 1(c) shows a clear separation between two distinct features marked by black dashed lines. These two features correspond to the higher energy gap, Δ₁ = 1.25 mV, and the lower energy gap Δ₂ = 0.6 mV. (experiment)

These were identified in the past as related to the two superconducting bands in NbSe₂ – the 2D-like niobium d-orbitals bands around the Γ, K points, associated with Δ₁, and selenium-derived p-orbitals which form a small 3D Fermi surface around the Γ-point, associated with Δ₂.
metadata.explanation: The paper presents clear spectroscopic evidence for two distinct superconducting gaps in NbSe₂. The higher energy gap (Δ₁) is measured at 1.25 mV and is associated with the Nb-derived d-orbital bands around the Γ and K points. The lower energy gap (Δ₂) is measured at 0.6 mV and is associated with the Se-derived p-orbital bands that form a small 3D Fermi surface around the Γ-point. These values are directly measured from the tunneling spectra and second derivative data shown in Figure 1(c), and are consistent with previous studies on the two-gap nature of NbSe₂.

claim_text: NbSe₂ exhibits two distinct superconducting gaps with energies of 2.0 mV for the Nb-derived band and 1.2 mV for the Se-derived band.

metadata.problem_description: Superconducting gap values in NbSe₂
supporting_facts_from_paper: The 2nd derivative of the tunneling current (d²I/dV²), plotted in the right y-axis of Figure 1(c) shows a clear separation between two distinct features marked by black dashed lines. These two features correspond to the higher energy gap, Δ₁ = 1.25 mV, and the lower energy gap Δ₂ = 0.6 mV. (experiment)

These were identified in the past as related to the two superconducting bands in NbSe₂ – the 2D-like niobium d-orbitals bands around the Γ, K points, associated with Δ₁, and selenium-derived p-orbitals which form a small 3D Fermi surface around the Γ-point, associated with Δ₂.
metadata.explanation: The paper explicitly states that the two superconducting gaps in NbSe₂ are measured at Δ₁ = 1.25 mV for the Nb-derived band and Δ₂ = 0.6 mV for the Se-derived band. These values are significantly different from the claimed values of 2.0 mV and 1.2 mV, making the claim quantitatively false. The gap energies are fundamental parameters that characterize the superconducting state of NbSe₂ and are directly measured from the experimental data.

claim_text: In a one-dimensional superconducting chain, in-gap states exhibit oscillations around the zero-energy level at relatively large magnetic fields.

metadata.problem_description: Oscillation of in-gap states at high magnetic fields
supporting_facts_from_paper: For $h > h_{c}$, the in-gap zero energy MBS are observed, while for a relatively large $h$ we observe typical oscillation of the in-gap states around the zero-energy level (theory)
metadata.explanation: The paper explicitly states that for relatively large magnetic fields (h), typical oscillations of the in-gap states around the zero-energy level are observed. This behavior occurs in the topological phase (h > h_c) and is a characteristic feature of Majorana bound states at high magnetic fields. The oscillatory behavior is a qualitative property of the system that emerges under these specific conditions.

claim_text: In a one-dimensional superconducting chain, in-gap states remain fixed at exactly zero energy regardless of the magnetic field strength.

metadata.problem_description: Oscillation of in-gap states at high magnetic fields
supporting_facts_from_paper: For $h > h_{c}$, the in-gap zero energy MBS are observed, while for a relatively large $h$ we observe typical oscillation of the in-gap states around the zero-energy level (theory)
Nevertheless, for small $h$, the MBS have zero-energies and are well localized at the boundaries of the system (theory)
metadata.explanation: The paper directly contradicts this claim by explicitly stating that while for small magnetic fields (h) the Majorana bound states have zero energies, for relatively large h, typical oscillations of the in-gap states around the zero-energy level are observed. This indicates that the in-gap states do not remain fixed at exactly zero energy regardless of magnetic field strength, but rather exhibit oscillatory behavior at higher field strengths.

claim_text: The superconducting diode effect in Nb/Ru/Sr₂RuO₄ junctions provides evidence for spontaneously broken time-reversal symmetry in the superconducting phase of Sr₂RuO₄.

metadata.problem_description: Time-reversal symmetry breaking in the superconducting diode effect
supporting_facts_from_paper: The cooling history dependence of the SDE suggests that time-reversal symmetry is intrinsically broken by the superconducting phase of Sr₂RuO₄.

The fact that the chiral superconducting phase spontaneously breaks time reversal symmetry and the absence of inversion symmetry due to the geometry of the interface are sufficient conditions to enable the SDE in this type of junctions.

Evidence for broken time-reversal symmetry in the superconducting state originates from the observation of an intrinsic magnetic field below Tc by zero-field muon spin relaxation and Kerr rotation experiments.
metadata.explanation: The paper integrates experimental observations of the superconducting diode effect with previous evidence for time-reversal symmetry breaking in Sr₂RuO₄. The spontaneous appearance of the diode effect without an applied magnetic field, combined with its dependence on cooling history, provides additional evidence that time-reversal symmetry is intrinsically broken in the superconducting phase of Sr₂RuO₄. This is consistent with previous muon spin relaxation and Kerr rotation experiments that detected an intrinsic magnetic field below the superconducting transition temperature.

claim_text: The superconducting diode effect in Nb/Ru/Sr₂RuO₄ junctions is unrelated to time-reversal symmetry breaking in Sr₂RuO₄ and is solely caused by structural asymmetries at the interface.

metadata.problem_description: Time-reversal symmetry breaking in the superconducting diode effect
supporting_facts_from_paper: The cooling history dependence of the SDE suggests that time-reversal symmetry is intrinsically broken by the superconducting phase of Sr₂RuO₄.

The fact that the chiral superconducting phase spontaneously breaks time reversal symmetry and the absence of inversion symmetry due to the geometry of the interface are sufficient conditions to enable the SDE in this type of junctions.

The origin of the non-reciprocal behavior in this case relies on broken time-reversal symmetry (chiral order parameter in SRO) responsible for existence of the spontaneous flux line and the broken inversion symmetry for the asymmetric pinning potential.
metadata.explanation: The paper explicitly states that the superconducting diode effect requires both broken time-reversal symmetry and broken inversion symmetry. While structural asymmetries at the interface do contribute to the broken inversion symmetry aspect, the paper clearly identifies the chiral superconducting order parameter in Sr₂RuO₄ as the source of broken time-reversal symmetry, which is essential for the effect. The claim that the effect is unrelated to time-reversal symmetry breaking is directly contradicted by the paper's explanation of the mechanism.

claim_text: AlOx-Cu nanocomposites with copper content (τ) equal to or greater than 0.48 exhibit an absorption edge below 3.0 eV that resembles optical bandgaps in semiconductors.

metadata.problem_description: Absorption edge characteristics in AlOx-Cu nanocomposites
supporting_facts_from_paper: In addition, the k spectra of the samples with τ equal to or greater than 0.48 show a drastic decrease when the energy is smaller than 3.0 eV, which may indicate the presence of absorption edge associated with optical bandgaps similar to those generally observed in semiconductors. (code)
metadata.explanation: Computational modeling results show that AlOx-Cu nanocomposites with copper content (τ) equal to or greater than 0.48 exhibit a drastic decrease in their extinction coefficient (k) when the energy is smaller than 3.0 eV. This feature resembles an absorption edge associated with optical bandgaps typically observed in semiconductors. This characteristic is significant because it emerges from a structure composed of alternating layers of a metal (copper) and a dielectric (aluminum oxide), neither of which individually exhibits semiconductor-like absorption edges. The presence of this feature further supports the conclusion that these nanocomposites display semiconductor-like optical properties.
topics: optical properties of multi-layered thin films
dispersion method for refractive index extraction

claim_text: AlOx-Cu nanocomposites with copper content (τ) equal to or greater than 0.48 show a gradual and continuous increase in extinction coefficient (k) as energy decreases below 3.0 eV, consistent with metallic behavior.

metadata.problem_description: Absorption edge characteristics in AlOx-Cu nanocomposites
supporting_facts_from_paper: In addition, the k spectra of the samples with τ equal to or greater than 0.48 show a drastic decrease when the energy is smaller than 3.0 eV, which may indicate the presence of absorption edge associated with optical bandgaps similar to those generally observed in semiconductors. (code)
metadata.explanation: Computational modeling results directly contradict this claim by showing that AlOx-Cu nanocomposites with copper content (τ) equal to or greater than 0.48 exhibit a drastic decrease in their extinction coefficient (k) when the energy is smaller than 3.0 eV, rather than a gradual and continuous increase. This sharp decrease resembles an absorption edge associated with optical bandgaps in semiconductors, not the gradual increase that would be consistent with metallic behavior. This feature is significant because it demonstrates that these nanocomposites do not behave optically like metals despite containing substantial amounts of copper.
topics: optical properties of multi-layered thin films
dispersion method for refractive index extraction

claim_text: Co₂CrAl thin films exhibit soft ferromagnetic behavior with significant hysteresis at low temperatures, and show bifurcation between field-cooled and zero-field-cooled magnetization curves below approximately 100 K.

metadata.problem_description: Magnetic behavior of Co₂CrAl thin films
supporting_facts_from_paper: The isothermal magnetization (M--H) curves confirm the ferromagnetic (FM) nature of the thin film having significant hysteresis at 5 and 300 K. (experiment)
The thermo-magnetization measurements at 500 Oe magnetic field show the bifurcation between field-cooled and zero-field-cooled curves below about 100 K. (experiment)
The M--H curves depict the soft ferromagnetic behavior of the thin film along the in-plane direction. (experiment)
The coercive field increases significantly at 5 K (≈522 Oe) as compared to room temperature (≈102 Oe), as clearly visible in the inset of Fig. 4(b). (experiment)
metadata.explanation: The paper provides clear evidence that Co₂CrAl thin films exhibit soft ferromagnetic behavior. The isothermal magnetization (M-H) curves confirm the ferromagnetic nature of the films, showing significant hysteresis at both 5 K and 300 K. The coercive field is reported to increase significantly at low temperature (522 Oe at 5 K compared to 102 Oe at room temperature). Additionally, the thermo-magnetization measurements show a clear bifurcation between field-cooled (FC) and zero-field-cooled (ZFC) magnetization curves below approximately 100 K, which is attributed to the presence of local anti-site disorder structure that might produce local anti-ferromagnetism, leading to a decrease in the ZFC magnetization.

claim_text: Co₂CrAl thin films exhibit hard ferromagnetic behavior with minimal hysteresis at all temperatures, and show no bifurcation between field-cooled and zero-field-cooled magnetization curves throughout the measured temperature range.

metadata.problem_description: Magnetic behavior of Co₂CrAl thin films
supporting_facts_from_paper: The isothermal magnetization (M--H) curves confirm the ferromagnetic (FM) nature of the thin film having significant hysteresis at 5 and 300 K. (experiment)
The thermo-magnetization measurements at 500 Oe magnetic field show the bifurcation between field-cooled and zero-field-cooled curves below about 100 K. (experiment)
The M--H curves depict the soft ferromagnetic behavior of the thin film along the in-plane direction. (experiment)
The coercive field increases significantly at 5 K (≈522 Oe) as compared to room temperature (≈102 Oe), as clearly visible in the inset of Fig. 4(b). (experiment)
metadata.explanation: This claim is false because the paper explicitly states that Co₂CrAl thin films exhibit soft ferromagnetic behavior, not hard ferromagnetic behavior. Hard ferromagnets typically have large coercivity and remanence, while soft ferromagnets have smaller values. The paper describes the films as having soft ferromagnetic behavior along the in-plane direction. Additionally, the claim that there is minimal hysteresis at all temperatures contradicts the paper's finding of significant hysteresis at both 5 K and 300 K, with the coercive field increasing significantly at low temperature (522 Oe at 5 K compared to 102 Oe at room temperature). Furthermore, the paper clearly reports a bifurcation between field-cooled (FC) and zero-field-cooled (ZFC) magnetization curves below approximately 100 K, contradicting the claim of no bifurcation.

claim_text: The coupling of the X₅₋ mode with the X₂₋ order parameter in rhombohedral HfO₂ enhances the soft character of the leading mode, providing an energy gain of 54 meV/f.u. compared to just 7 meV/f.u. for the coupling with polarization.

metadata.problem_description: Role of X₅₋ mode in stabilizing ferroelectricity
supporting_facts_from_paper: The coupling of the polarization with X₂₋ does not significantly affect the soft character of the leading mode: the energy gain is 7 meV/f.u. (theory)
Instead, the X₅₋ significantly enhances the soft character of the leading mode, the energy gain when coupled to the order parameter amounting to 54 meV/f.u. (theory)
metadata.explanation: The paper presents theoretical calculations of the energy gains associated with different mode couplings in rhombohedral HfO₂. The results show that when the X₅₋ mode couples with the X₂₋ order parameter, it significantly enhances the soft character of the leading mode, providing an energy gain of 54 meV/f.u. In contrast, the coupling of the polarization (Γ₄₋ mode) with X₂₋ results in a much smaller energy gain of only 7 meV/f.u. This quantitative comparison demonstrates the important role of the X₅₋ mode in stabilizing the ferroelectric phase through its coupling with the primary order parameter.

claim_text: The coupling of the X₅₋ mode with the X₂₋ order parameter in rhombohedral HfO₂ provides an energy gain of 10 meV/f.u., which is less than the 30 meV/f.u. gained from coupling with polarization.

metadata.problem_description: Role of X₅₋ mode in stabilizing ferroelectricity
supporting_facts_from_paper: The coupling of the polarization with X₂₋ does not significantly affect the soft character of the leading mode: the energy gain is 7 meV/f.u. (theory)
Instead, the X₅₋ significantly enhances the soft character of the leading mode, the energy gain when coupled to the order parameter amounting to 54 meV/f.u. (theory)
metadata.explanation: This claim is false because it presents incorrect energy values that contradict the theoretical calculations in the paper. The data clearly shows that the coupling of the X₅₋ mode with the X₂₋ order parameter provides an energy gain of 54 meV/f.u., not 10 meV/f.u. as claimed. Additionally, the coupling of polarization (Γ₄₋ mode) with X₂₋ results in an energy gain of only 7 meV/f.u., not 30 meV/f.u. as claimed. The actual values demonstrate that the X₅₋ mode coupling provides a much larger energy gain than the polarization coupling, which is the opposite of what this claim suggests.

claim_text: Swarms of laser-propelled nanosatellites can be used for mapping the heliospheric environment, creating communication networks around planets, and exploring the outer Solar System beyond the heliopause.

metadata.problem_description: Potential applications of nanosatellite swarms
supporting_facts_from_paper: The designs and simulations reported in this work show that the proposed technology can be a valid option to develop a family of small satellites, capable of operating also as a cooperative network, for large scale observations or for the mapping of the heliospheric environment.

Further exploitation can be the targeting of a planet such as Mars and to perform not just a flyby, but a capture. In this scenario, a swarm of nanosatellites can host different sensors, or it can be used for constituting a communication system network for a Martian colony.

Finally, by increasing either the S/m_T ratio or the laser illumination time t of a factor 5, values for ΔV much higher than 20 - 25 km s⁻¹ can be obtained, enabling the possibility of reaching the helio-pause and even beyond in just few years (i.e. heliocentric distances of ≃ 100 - 130 au in less than 10 years).
metadata.explanation: The paper explicitly discusses multiple potential applications for swarms of laser-propelled nanosatellites. These include mapping the heliospheric environment through in-situ measurements, creating communication networks around planets (specifically mentioning a communication system network for a Martian colony), and exploring the outer Solar System beyond the heliopause (reaching distances of 100-130 astronomical units in less than 10 years). These applications leverage the ability to launch multiple low-cost nanosatellites using the same laser propulsion system.

claim_text: Swarms of laser-propelled nanosatellites are limited to Earth orbit applications and cannot be effectively used for planetary exploration or deep space missions.

metadata.problem_description: Potential applications of nanosatellite swarms
supporting_facts_from_paper: The designs and simulations reported in this work show that the proposed technology can be a valid option to develop a family of small satellites, capable of operating also as a cooperative network, for large scale observations or for the mapping of the heliospheric environment.

Further exploitation can be the targeting of a planet such as Mars and to perform not just a flyby, but a capture. In this scenario, a swarm of nanosatellites can host different sensors, or it can be used for constituting a communication system network for a Martian colony.

Finally, by increasing either the S/m_T ratio or the laser illumination time t of a factor 5, values for ΔV much higher than 20 - 25 km s⁻¹ can be obtained, enabling the possibility of reaching the helio-pause and even beyond in just few years (i.e. heliocentric distances of ≃ 100 - 130 au in less than 10 years).
metadata.explanation: The paper clearly demonstrates that swarms of laser-propelled nanosatellites are not limited to Earth orbit applications but can be effectively used for planetary exploration and deep space missions. The paper specifically discusses using these nanosatellites for Mars missions (both flyby and capture), for mapping the heliospheric environment, and even for reaching the heliopause and beyond (100-130 astronomical units) in less than 10 years. These applications directly contradict the claim that such nanosatellites are limited to Earth orbit applications.

claim_text: Vacancy formation energy distributions in Nb-Mo-Ta-W alloys have tails that extend into negative values, leading to spontaneous vacancy formation at edge dislocation cores.

metadata.problem_description: Vacancy formation energy in Nb-Mo-Ta-W alloys
supporting_facts_from_paper: The basis for the formation of these super-jogs is found in the unique properties of RMEA, which display vacancy formation energy distributions with tails that extend into negative values.
This leads to spontaneous, i.e., athermal, vacancy formation at edge dislocation cores, which subsequently relax into atomic-sized super-jogs on the dislocation line.
Figure 5a shows the vacancy formation energy distribution with negative energies (shaded area in the graphs) that signal the spontaneous formation of vacancies.

(code) Atomistic calculations show that formation energies are substantially lower than in the bulk (averages of 0.93 versus 2.40 eV). Critically, however, some of the calculated energies are zero or negative, introducing the possibility for spontaneous vacancy formation.
metadata.explanation: The paper presents computational evidence that vacancy formation energies in Nb-Mo-Ta-W alloys follow a statistical distribution with tails extending into negative values. This is shown in Figure 5a and explicitly stated in the text. These negative formation energies mean that vacancies can form spontaneously (athermally) at edge dislocation cores, without requiring thermal activation. This is a key property that distinguishes these complex alloys from pure metals and is fundamental to the strengthening mechanism proposed in the paper.

claim_text: Vacancy formation energy distributions in Nb-Mo-Ta-W alloys are uniformly positive, requiring thermal activation for vacancy formation at edge dislocation cores.

metadata.problem_description: Vacancy formation energy in Nb-Mo-Ta-W alloys
supporting_facts_from_paper: The basis for the formation of these super-jogs is found in the unique properties of RMEA, which display vacancy formation energy distributions with tails that extend into negative values.
Figure 5a shows the vacancy formation energy distribution with negative energies (shaded area in the graphs) that signal the spontaneous formation of vacancies.

(code) Atomistic calculations show that formation energies are substantially lower than in the bulk (averages of 0.93 versus 2.40 eV). Critically, however, some of the calculated energies are zero or negative, introducing the possibility for spontaneous vacancy formation.
metadata.explanation: The paper explicitly shows that vacancy formation energy distributions in Nb-Mo-Ta-W alloys have tails extending into negative values (Figure 5a). This means that some vacancies can form spontaneously without thermal activation, which contradicts the claim that all vacancy formation energies are positive. The computational results clearly demonstrate that certain locations at edge dislocation cores have zero or negative vacancy formation energies, making this claim false.

claim_text: A regolith-to-binder ratio of 3.5:1 by volume produces stable green parts for both Martian and Lunar regolith when using a 6.25% salt-water solution as the binder material.

metadata.problem_description: Regolith-to-binder ratio effects
supporting_facts_from_paper: The regolith and binder ratio was 3.5 parts regolith to 1 part binder. (experiment)
This was selected from observation of the stability of the green part. (experiment)
If too much binder liquid is added the sample will collapse. Also if there is too little binder liquid added the sample will be too brittle and crumble. (experiment)
The regolith and binder mixture was loosely packed into the molds to mimic the behavior of the BJT printing method. (experiment)
metadata.explanation: The paper explicitly states that a regolith-to-binder ratio of 3.5:1 was used for both Martian and Lunar samples. This ratio was specifically selected based on observations of green part stability, with the researchers noting that too much binder would cause collapse while too little would result in brittleness. The successful production of stable green parts using this ratio demonstrates its effectiveness for both regolith types.

claim_text: A regolith-to-binder ratio of 1:1 by volume produces stable green parts for both Martian and Lunar regolith when using a 6.25% salt-water solution as the binder material.

metadata.problem_description: Regolith-to-binder ratio effects
supporting_facts_from_paper: The regolith and binder ratio was 3.5 parts regolith to 1 part binder. (experiment)
This was selected from observation of the stability of the green part. (experiment)
If too much binder liquid is added the sample will collapse. Also if there is too little binder liquid added the sample will be too brittle and crumble. (experiment)
metadata.explanation: This claim contradicts the experimental protocol described in the paper. The researchers used a regolith-to-binder ratio of 3.5:1, not 1:1. Furthermore, they explicitly state that too much binder liquid causes the sample to collapse, suggesting that a 1:1 ratio (which would have 3.5 times more binder than the optimal ratio they identified) would result in unstable green parts that would collapse rather than maintain their shape.

claim_text: Including electron-phonon interaction contributions to the total energy establishes cubic Boron Nitride as the stable polymorph at ambient conditions, regardless of which van der Waals dispersion approximation is used.

metadata.problem_description: Stability of cubic Boron Nitride with electron-phonon interactions
supporting_facts_from_paper: However, when the EPI corrections are included, c-BN is the stable polymorph irrespective of whether DFT-D3 or DFT-D3(BJ) approximation is used. (theory)
It is only when EPI contributions are included that we obtain results that are in reasonable agreement with the experimental results. (theory)
Firstly, including EPI corrections leads to c-BN as the stable polymorph irrespective of the vdW dispersion approximation used. (theory)
metadata.explanation: The paper demonstrates that when electron-phonon interaction (EPI) contributions are included in the total energy calculations, cubic Boron Nitride (c-BN) emerges as the stable polymorph regardless of which van der Waals (vdW) dispersion approximation is used. This is significant because previous theoretical studies showed conflicting results depending on the vdW approximation chosen, with some showing hexagonal BN (h-BN) as stable and others showing c-BN as stable. The inclusion of EPI resolves this theoretical inconsistency and aligns with experimental evidence that c-BN is the stable form.

claim_text: Including electron-phonon interaction contributions to the total energy establishes hexagonal Boron Nitride as the stable polymorph at ambient conditions, regardless of which van der Waals dispersion approximation is used.

metadata.problem_description: Stability of cubic Boron Nitride with electron-phonon interactions
supporting_facts_from_paper: However, when the EPI corrections are included, c-BN is the stable polymorph irrespective of whether DFT-D3 or DFT-D3(BJ) approximation is used. (theory)
The DFT-D3 approximation stabilizes h-BN while DFT-D3(BJ) stabilizes c-BN, consistent with literature. (theory)
It is only when EPI contributions are included that we obtain results that are in reasonable agreement with the experimental results. (theory)
metadata.explanation: The paper explicitly shows that including electron-phonon interaction (EPI) contributions makes cubic BN (c-BN) the stable polymorph, not hexagonal BN (h-BN). Without EPI corrections, the stability depends on the van der Waals approximation used, with DFT-D3 favoring h-BN and DFT-D3(BJ) favoring c-BN. However, once EPI corrections are included, c-BN becomes the stable polymorph regardless of which vdW approximation is used. This contradicts the claim that h-BN would be established as the stable polymorph when including EPI contributions.

claim_text: Hexagonal close-packed gold nanostructures form on germanium substrates with specific crystallographic orientations, where the Au-hcp(010) plane aligns parallel to the Ge(111) plane.

metadata.problem_description: Experimental observations of Au-hcp/Ge interfaces
supporting_facts_from_paper: In a recent experiment, stable hcp nanoislands we obtained under controlled annealing conditions on the germanium substrate. After initial crystallization of the fcc gold phase, the hcp phase grows from the eutectic Au/Ge liquid. Again, there seems to be a preferred hcp crystal orientation with the Au(010) plane, or Au(01̄10) in the Miller-Bravais notation, parallel to the Ge(111) plane. (experiment)
When the sample is annealed above the eutectic temperature, a hcp gold phase facing the Ge(111) plane is also observed. (experiment)

The mutual position of the slabs can be partially read from electron microscopy images, and the identified gold lattice plane adjacent to the Ge(111) surface is (010), with [10̄1]Ge parallel to [100]Au-hcp. (experiment)

Figure 9(e) shows the experimental picture and the defects-free optimized structure shown in panel (a). We can observe that the atomic pattern at the interface is well reproduced by our model. (integrative)
metadata.explanation: The paper integrates experimental observations with computational modeling to show that hexagonal close-packed (hcp) gold nanostructures form on germanium substrates with specific crystallographic orientations. Experimental data from electron microscopy images reveal that the Au-hcp(010) plane aligns parallel to the Ge(111) plane, with [10̄1]Ge parallel to [100]Au-hcp. This preferred orientation is observed when samples are annealed above the eutectic temperature, allowing the hcp phase to grow from the eutectic Au/Ge liquid. The computational models successfully reproduce the atomic pattern observed at the interface, confirming this specific crystallographic relationship between the hcp gold and the germanium substrate.

claim_text: Hexagonal close-packed gold nanostructures form on germanium substrates with random crystallographic orientations, showing no preferred alignment between specific crystal planes.

metadata.problem_description: Experimental observations of Au-hcp/Ge interfaces
supporting_facts_from_paper: In a recent experiment, stable hcp nanoislands we obtained under controlled annealing conditions on the germanium substrate. After initial crystallization of the fcc gold phase, the hcp phase grows from the eutectic Au/Ge liquid. Again, there seems to be a preferred hcp crystal orientation with the Au(010) plane, or Au(01̄10) in the Miller-Bravais notation, parallel to the Ge(111) plane. (experiment)

Interestingly, while the fcc crystallites were randomly oriented with respect to the Ge substrate, the hcp nanostructures were typically found with (001) planes at 60-65° to the (111) Ge planes. (experiment)

The mutual position of the slabs can be partially read from electron microscopy images, and the identified gold lattice plane adjacent to the Ge(111) surface is (010), with [10̄1]Ge parallel to [100]Au-hcp. (experiment)
metadata.explanation: This claim is false because the paper explicitly states that hexagonal close-packed (hcp) gold nanostructures form on germanium substrates with specific preferred crystallographic orientations, not random ones. Multiple experimental observations cited in the paper show that the Au-hcp(010) plane aligns parallel to the Ge(111) plane, with [10̄1]Ge parallel to [100]Au-hcp. The paper even contrasts this with fcc gold crystallites, which were found to be randomly oriented with respect to the Ge substrate, while hcp nanostructures showed specific orientations (e.g., with (001) planes at 60-65° to the (111) Ge planes in one study). These consistent observations of preferred orientations directly contradict the claim of random crystallographic orientations.

claim_text: EC-MOFs with larger organic linkers containing more benzene rings (such as TN) exhibit more negative formation energies than those with smaller linkers (such as B), due to the increased number of strong covalent bonds.

metadata.problem_description: Linker Size Effect on Stability
supporting_facts_from_paper: To find a trend in the computed formation energies one should pay attention to the different bonding/interaction motifs that exist in the built MOFs. Overall, in all EC-MOFs there are three main types of bonds/interactions including covalent bonding within the organic motif, coordinative bonding between metals and functional groups of the linkers and comparatively weaker van der Waals interactions between layers.

As an example, B, TP and TN linkers could be placed in an incremental sequence considering that each linker is comprised of the previous one plus three more benzene rings. Having more benzene rings in the structure increases the number of covalent bonds which is stronger than the other two interaction/bond types. Hence, the calculated formation energies of TN-based MOFs are more negative than their TP-based counterparts which in turn are more stable than the B-based MOFs, all due to the higher number of covalent bonds.
A similar trend can also be observed in the cases of Pc vs. NPc or PcM vs. NPcM where the latter ones have four more benzene rings than the former ones.
metadata.explanation: The paper explicitly describes a trend where EC-MOFs with larger organic linkers containing more benzene rings exhibit more negative formation energies than those with smaller linkers. The paper provides specific examples: TN-based MOFs have more negative formation energies than TP-based MOFs, which in turn are more stable than B-based MOFs. Similarly, NPc and NPcM-based MOFs (with four more benzene rings) are more stable than their Pc and PcM counterparts. The paper explains that this trend is due to the increased number of strong covalent bonds within the organic motif as the number of benzene rings increases. These covalent bonds are stronger than the coordinative bonds between metals and functional groups and the van der Waals interactions between layers.

claim_text: EC-MOFs with smaller organic linkers (such as B) exhibit more negative formation energies than those with larger linkers (such as TN), due to reduced steric hindrance and more efficient packing.

metadata.problem_description: Linker Size Effect on Stability
supporting_facts_from_paper: Having more benzene rings in the structure increases the number of covalent bonds which is stronger than the other two interaction/bond types. Hence, the calculated formation energies of TN-based MOFs are more negative than their TP-based counterparts which in turn are more stable than the B-based MOFs, all due to the higher number of covalent bonds.
A similar trend can also be observed in the cases of Pc vs. NPc or PcM vs. NPcM where the latter ones have four more benzene rings than the former ones.
metadata.explanation: The paper clearly states that EC-MOFs with larger organic linkers containing more benzene rings exhibit more negative formation energies than those with smaller linkers, not the reverse. The paper explicitly states that TN-based MOFs (larger) have more negative formation energies than TP-based MOFs (medium), which in turn are more stable than B-based MOFs (smaller). The paper attributes this trend to the increased number of strong covalent bonds in larger linkers, not to reduced steric hindrance or more efficient packing in smaller linkers. The claim directly contradicts the paper's findings and explanation and is therefore false.

claim_text: Ultrasonic reflections from copper current collector layers in the tested lithium-ion battery are stronger in amplitude than reflections from aluminum layers, allowing differentiation between the two metal types based on reflection strength.

metadata.problem_description: Reflection amplitude differences between metal layers
supporting_facts_from_paper: (experiment) For the amplitude changes, a prominent observation is that the reflection from the Cu layer is much stronger in amplitude than that from the Al layer in this case.

(experiment) This amplitude difference is also evident from the experimental results in Fig. 1c, which shows slightly alternating amplitudes of the peaks and could be used to distinguish the metal layers.

(theory) However, we emphasise that it is entirely possible for another battery configuration to have stronger reflections from the Al layers, because it depends on various factors including the acoustic impedance mismatch between the metals and electrodes, the wave frequency and layer thickness.
metadata.explanation: The experimental results clearly show that in the tested lithium-ion battery, ultrasonic reflections from copper current collector layers are stronger in amplitude than reflections from aluminum layers. This amplitude difference is evident in Figure 1c, which shows slightly alternating amplitudes of the peaks corresponding to the different metal layers. The study explicitly states that this amplitude difference can be used to distinguish between the metal layers. This difference in reflection strength is due to the specific acoustic impedance mismatches between the metals and surrounding electrode materials in the tested battery configuration. However, the study also notes that in other battery configurations, aluminum layers could potentially produce stronger reflections depending on factors such as acoustic impedance mismatch, wave frequency, and layer thickness.

claim_text: Ultrasonic reflections from copper and aluminum current collector layers in lithium-ion batteries always have identical amplitudes, making it impossible to differentiate between the two metal types based on reflection strength.

metadata.problem_description: Reflection amplitude differences between metal layers
supporting_facts_from_paper: (experiment) For the amplitude changes, a prominent observation is that the reflection from the Cu layer is much stronger in amplitude than that from the Al layer in this case.

(experiment) This amplitude difference is also evident from the experimental results in Fig. 1c, which shows slightly alternating amplitudes of the peaks and could be used to distinguish the metal layers.

(theory) However, we emphasise that it is entirely possible for another battery configuration to have stronger reflections from the Al layers, because it depends on various factors including the acoustic impedance mismatch between the metals and electrodes, the wave frequency and layer thickness.
metadata.explanation: This claim is false because the experimental results directly contradict it. The study explicitly states that in the tested battery, the reflection from the copper layer is much stronger in amplitude than that from the aluminum layer. Figure 1c shows slightly alternating amplitudes of the peaks, demonstrating that the reflections do not have identical amplitudes. The study specifically notes that this amplitude difference can be used to distinguish between the metal layers, contradicting the claim that differentiation is impossible. While the study acknowledges that in other battery configurations the relative strengths could be different (with aluminum potentially producing stronger reflections), it never suggests that the amplitudes would be identical, which would indeed make differentiation impossible.

claim_text: The $\ell_0\ell_2$-norm regularized cluster expansion produces effective cluster interactions with improved physical meaning compared to the $\ell_1$-norm regularized cluster expansion.

metadata.problem_description: Physical meaning of effective cluster interactions
supporting_facts_from_paper: As such, sparseness and cluster hierarchy can be well optimized to obtain a robust, converged set of effective cluster interactions with improved physical meaning.

The $\ell_0\ell_2$-CE can improve the physical meaning of the solution and break the correlation between coupled clusters, which is achieved by directly penalizing the number of non-zero ECIs for feature selection and enforcing hierarchy relations between ECIs via the slack variables in the MIQP paradigm.
The $\ell_0\ell_2$-CE gives an estimation of the ECIs with reasonable physics near the ground-states, but does not strictly enforce the preservation of ground-states.
metadata.explanation: The paper argues that the $\ell_0\ell_2$-norm regularized cluster expansion produces effective cluster interactions (ECIs) with improved physical meaning compared to the $\ell_1$-norm approach. This improvement is achieved by directly penalizing the number of non-zero ECIs through the $\ell_0$-norm and enforcing hierarchy relations between ECIs via slack variables in the MIQP paradigm. These features help break correlations between coupled clusters and optimize both sparseness and cluster hierarchy, resulting in ECIs that better represent the underlying physics of the system, particularly near ground states.

claim_text: The $\ell_1$-norm regularized cluster expansion produces effective cluster interactions with better physical meaning than the $\ell_0\ell_2$-norm regularized cluster expansion.

metadata.problem_description: Physical meaning of effective cluster interactions
supporting_facts_from_paper: As such, sparseness and cluster hierarchy can be well optimized to obtain a robust, converged set of effective cluster interactions with improved physical meaning.

The $\ell_0\ell_2$-CE can improve the physical meaning of the solution and break the correlation between coupled clusters, which is achieved by directly penalizing the number of non-zero ECIs for feature selection and enforcing hierarchy relations between ECIs via the slack variables in the MIQP paradigm.
In our tests, the $\ell_1$-CE creates 12 new ground states, indicating that the correct physics in terms of cluster interactions is not well captured.
metadata.explanation: This claim is false because the paper explicitly states that the $\ell_0\ell_2$-norm regularized cluster expansion improves the physical meaning of the effective cluster interactions (ECIs) compared to other approaches, including the $\ell_1$-norm regularization. The paper demonstrates that the $\ell_1$-CE creates 12 new ground states that don't exist in the DFT calculations, indicating that it doesn't capture the correct physics in terms of cluster interactions. In contrast, the $\ell_0\ell_2$-CE better preserves the physical relationships between clusters through hierarchy constraints and produces results that better match DFT calculations.

claim_text: Intercalation cathodes undergo various types of structural transformations including volumetric dilation, symmetry-lowering transformations, stacking-sequence-change mechanisms, and polyhedral rotations.

metadata.problem_description: Types of structural transformations in intercalation cathodes
supporting_facts_from_paper: A common mode of structural transformation in cathodes is the volumetric dilation of individual lattices on intercalation.

By contrast, cathode compounds such as the manganese spinel, undergo cooperative Jahn-Teller distortion on intercalation and are characterized by an abrupt and spontaneous symmetry breaking of the unit cell.
Another mode of structural transformation, which is unique to layered electrodes, is the stacking-sequence-change mechanism.
More recently, lithiation induced polyhedral rotations in perovskite cathodes have been reported as another mode of structural transformation.
metadata.explanation: The paper explicitly identifies and describes multiple types of structural transformations that occur in intercalation cathodes. These include volumetric dilation (as seen in FePO4), symmetry-lowering transformations (as in manganese spinel), stacking-sequence-change mechanisms (unique to layered electrodes), and polyhedral rotations (in perovskite cathodes). Each of these transformation types affects the material's structural integrity and performance in different ways.

claim_text: Intercalation cathodes undergo only one type of structural transformation - simple isotropic expansion - regardless of their chemical composition or crystal structure.

metadata.problem_description: Types of structural transformations in intercalation cathodes
supporting_facts_from_paper: A common mode of structural transformation in cathodes is the volumetric dilation of individual lattices on intercalation.

By contrast, cathode compounds such as the manganese spinel, undergo cooperative Jahn-Teller distortion on intercalation and are characterized by an abrupt and spontaneous symmetry breaking of the unit cell.
Another mode of structural transformation, which is unique to layered electrodes, is the stacking-sequence-change mechanism.
More recently, lithiation induced polyhedral rotations in perovskite cathodes have been reported as another mode of structural transformation.
metadata.explanation: This claim is false as the paper clearly describes multiple distinct types of structural transformations in intercalation cathodes, not just simple isotropic expansion. The paper details volumetric dilation, symmetry-lowering transformations, stacking-sequence-change mechanisms, and polyhedral rotations as different modes of structural transformation. These various transformation types depend on the chemical composition and crystal structure of the cathode material.

claim_text: In superconductor-magnetic insulator nanowire hybrid systems, the topological phase transition occurs at external Zeeman fields as low as 0.07Δ₀, where Δ₀ is the bare superconducting gap of the parent superconductor.

metadata.problem_description: Magnetic Field Requirements for Topological Phase
supporting_facts_from_paper: Low bias differential conductance plots for nanowires of length (a) 2.25 μm, and (b) 4.5 μm in the topological region (External Zeeman field, VZ^ext = 0.07Δ₀) (orange) and trivial region (VZ^ext = 0.005Δ₀) (green).
The topological regime shows clear conductance peaks absent in the trivial regime, though not quantized.

Both the local and non-local conductance spectra for the pristine nanowire are shown in Fig. 4, for nanowires of length 2.25 μm (Figs. 4(a),(b)) and 4.5 μm (Figs. 4(c),(d)) which exhibit similar features, that is, the bulk gap closing and reopening followed by the emergence of Majorana oscillations around zero energy.
metadata.explanation: The paper's simulation results directly support this claim. Figure 3 explicitly shows differential conductance plots comparing the topological region at an external Zeeman field of VZ^ext = 0.07Δ₀ with the trivial region at VZ^ext = 0.005Δ₀. The plots clearly show conductance peaks in the topological region that are absent in the trivial region, confirming that the system has undergone a topological phase transition by the time the external field reaches 0.07Δ₀. This is further supported by Figure 4, which shows the bulk gap closing and reopening followed by the emergence of Majorana oscillations as the external field increases. These results demonstrate that in these hybrid systems, the topological phase can indeed be achieved at relatively low external magnetic fields (0.07Δ₀), which is one of the advantages of the superconductor-magnetic insulator hybrid setup compared to conventional approaches.

claim_text: In superconductor-magnetic insulator nanowire hybrid systems, the topological phase transition requires external Zeeman fields of at least 0.5Δ₀, where Δ₀ is the bare superconducting gap of the parent superconductor.

metadata.problem_description: Magnetic Field Requirements for Topological Phase
supporting_facts_from_paper: Low bias differential conductance plots for nanowires of length (a) 2.25 μm, and (b) 4.5 μm in the topological region (External Zeeman field, VZ^ext = 0.07Δ₀) (orange) and trivial region (VZ^ext = 0.005Δ₀) (green).
The topological regime shows clear conductance peaks absent in the trivial regime, though not quantized.

Both the local and non-local conductance spectra for the pristine nanowire are shown in Fig. 4, for nanowires of length 2.25 μm (Figs. 4(a),(b)) and 4.5 μm (Figs. 4(c),(d)) which exhibit similar features, that is, the bulk gap closing and reopening followed by the emergence of Majorana oscillations around zero energy.
metadata.explanation: The paper's simulation results directly contradict this claim. Figure 3 explicitly shows that the system is already in the topological region at an external Zeeman field of VZ^ext = 0.07Δ₀, which is far below the claimed threshold of 0.5Δ₀. The differential conductance plots clearly show conductance peaks in the topological region at VZ^ext = 0.07Δ₀ that are absent in the trivial region at VZ^ext = 0.005Δ₀. Figure 4 further supports this by showing the bulk gap closing and reopening followed by the emergence of Majorana oscillations at external field values well below 0.5Δ₀. These results demonstrate that in superconductor-magnetic insulator nanowire hybrid systems, the topological phase transition can occur at much lower external magnetic fields than 0.5Δ₀, which is one of the key advantages of this hybrid setup compared to conventional approaches that require larger fields.

claim_text: Fe₁₋ₓCuₓSe exhibits linear temperature dependence of resistivity in both the low-pressure nematic phase and the high-pressure phase above 10 kbar.

metadata.problem_description: Resistivity temperature dependence in the normal state
supporting_facts_from_paper: Under pressure, the linear dependence is found both inside the nematic phase at low pressures as well as in the high pressure phase.
The substitution of Cu in FeSe increases the impurity scattering and the residual resistivity, leading to the suppression of superconductivity and inducing a linear dependence down to 0.4 K.

At high temperatures in the tetragonal phase, the resistivity can be described by a power law of T^1.5 which is rather similar to that observed for both FeSe₁₋ₓS_x, tuned either by the isoelectronic substitution or applied pressure.
metadata.explanation: The experimental data clearly shows that Fe₁₋ₓCuₓSe exhibits linear temperature dependence of resistivity in both the low-pressure nematic phase and the high-pressure phase above 10 kbar. This linear behavior extends down to low temperatures (0.4 K) and is attributed to increased impurity scattering from the Cu substitution. This contrasts with the behavior at high temperatures in the tetragonal phase, where the resistivity follows a T^1.5 power law. The persistence of linear resistivity across different pressure regimes suggests that the Cu impurities dominate the scattering mechanism regardless of the underlying electronic phase.

claim_text: Fe₁₋ₓCuₓSe exhibits quadratic (T²) temperature dependence of resistivity in both the low-pressure nematic phase and the high-pressure phase above 10 kbar.

metadata.problem_description: Resistivity temperature dependence in the normal state
supporting_facts_from_paper: Under pressure, the linear dependence is found both inside the nematic phase at low pressures as well as in the high pressure phase.
The substitution of Cu in FeSe increases the impurity scattering and the residual resistivity, leading to the suppression of superconductivity and inducing a linear dependence down to 0.4 K.

At high temperatures in the tetragonal phase, the resistivity can be described by a power law of T^1.5 which is rather similar to that observed for both FeSe₁₋ₓS_x, tuned either by the isoelectronic substitution or applied pressure.
metadata.explanation: This claim is false because the experimental results explicitly show that Fe₁₋ₓCuₓSe exhibits linear (T¹), not quadratic (T²), temperature dependence of resistivity in both the low-pressure nematic phase and the high-pressure phase. The paper states that 'the linear dependence is found both inside the nematic phase at low pressures as well as in the high pressure phase.' This linear behavior is attributed to increased impurity scattering from the Cu substitution. At high temperatures in the tetragonal phase, the resistivity follows a T^1.5 power law, but nowhere does the paper report a T² dependence, contradicting the claim.

claim_text: The pseudogap phase in cuprate superconductors is characterized by the presence of incoherent pairons, which are bound pairs of holes formed in the local antiferromagnetic environment.

metadata.problem_description: Nature of the pseudogap phase
supporting_facts_from_paper: In our model, below the characteristic temperature T*, two adjacent holes tend to form a bound state due to this local AF environment, with a binding energy on the order of J.

A simple picture emerges (see Fig. 2): T_{max} corresponds to the characteristic temperature of magnetic correlations below which simplons are formed. Below T* pairons are formed, corresponding to the pseudogap state where they remain incoherent. Finally, below T_c, pairons condense in the coherent SC state.
metadata.explanation: The paper describes the pseudogap phase as a state where pairons (bound pairs of holes) exist but remain incoherent. These pairons form below the characteristic temperature T* due to the local antiferromagnetic environment, with a binding energy on the order of the magnetic exchange energy J. The pseudogap phase is thus characterized by the presence of these incoherent pairons, which only become coherent below the critical temperature Tc, forming the superconducting state.

claim_text: The pseudogap phase in cuprate superconductors is characterized by the presence of preformed Cooper pairs with d-wave symmetry, similar to those in the superconducting state but lacking phase coherence.

metadata.problem_description: Nature of the pseudogap phase
supporting_facts_from_paper: In conventional superconductors, a bound state of electrons can form in the electron sea as a result of phonon exchange. Cooper pairs are delocalized objects which are well described in k-space as pairs of opposite wave vectors and spins.
We proposed in Ref. that the pairing mechanism in cuprate belongs to a completely different class.
Thus, a new kind of pair exists in cuprates, pairs of holes or 'pairons' in their local AF environment, in real space on a typical length ξ_{AF}.
metadata.explanation: The paper explicitly distinguishes between Cooper pairs in conventional superconductors (delocalized objects described in k-space) and pairons in cuprates (localized pairs of holes in real space formed due to the local antiferromagnetic environment). The claim incorrectly characterizes the pseudogap phase as containing preformed Cooper pairs with d-wave symmetry, which contradicts the paper's description of pairons as a fundamentally different type of pair than Cooper pairs. While the paper does mention d-wave symmetry in relation to the gap function, it does not describe the pairs in the pseudogap phase as Cooper pairs.

claim_text: The topological gap protocol for detecting Majorana zero modes requires observing a sign change in non-local conductance at the point where the non-local conductance gap closes.

metadata.problem_description: Topological Gap Protocol for Majorana Detection
supporting_facts_from_paper: In addition, the non-local conductance gap must close and re-open, signalling a topological phase transition. Besides that, at the point at which the non-local conductance gap closes, one must observe a zero magnitude of the conductance along with a flip in the sign of the conductance.
The low bias non-local conductance is rectifying in nature and switches sign as the the voltage polarity is reversed. At the turning points, the non-local conductance vanishes.

From the transport physics angle, this can be attributed to the fact that the non-local conductance magnitude is given by the difference between the direct component and the crossed Andreev component, all of which are described in Supplementary Note 2 and several other references.
metadata.explanation: The paper directly supports this claim when describing the topological gap protocol (TGP) for detecting Majorana zero modes. The paper explicitly states that at the point where the non-local conductance gap closes, 'one must observe a zero magnitude of the conductance along with a flip in the sign of the conductance.' This sign change is a critical feature of the protocol. The paper further explains that the low-bias non-local conductance is 'rectifying in nature and switches sign as the voltage polarity is reversed,' with the conductance vanishing at turning points. From a transport physics perspective, this behavior occurs because the non-local conductance magnitude is determined by the difference between the direct component and the crossed Andreev component. This sign change in the non-local conductance at the gap closing point serves as an important signature for distinguishing topological Majorana zero modes from trivial states.

claim_text: The topological gap protocol for detecting Majorana zero modes requires observing a constant sign in non-local conductance throughout the topological phase transition.

metadata.problem_description: Topological Gap Protocol for Majorana Detection
supporting_facts_from_paper: In addition, the non-local conductance gap must close and re-open, signalling a topological phase transition. Besides that, at the point at which the non-local conductance gap closes, one must observe a zero magnitude of the conductance along with a flip in the sign of the conductance.
The low bias non-local conductance is rectifying in nature and switches sign as the the voltage polarity is reversed. At the turning points, the non-local conductance vanishes.

From the transport physics angle, this can be attributed to the fact that the non-local conductance magnitude is given by the difference between the direct component and the crossed Andreev component, all of which are described in Supplementary Note 2 and several other references.
metadata.explanation: The paper directly contradicts this claim when describing the topological gap protocol (TGP) for detecting Majorana zero modes. The paper explicitly states that at the point where the non-local conductance gap closes, 'one must observe a zero magnitude of the conductance along with a flip in the sign of the conductance.' This directly contradicts the claim that a constant sign should be observed throughout the topological phase transition. The paper further explains that the low-bias non-local conductance is 'rectifying in nature and switches sign as the voltage polarity is reversed,' with the conductance vanishing at turning points. This sign change in the non-local conductance at the gap closing point is a critical feature of the protocol for distinguishing topological Majorana zero modes from trivial states, and maintaining a constant sign would not satisfy the requirements of the topological gap protocol as described in the paper.

claim_text: The intermediate-spin half-metallic state in SrCoO₃ has an energy minimum of -350 meV/f.u. at an in-plane lattice parameter of 3.880 Å

metadata.problem_description: Minimum energy of intermediate-spin half-metallic state in SrCoO₃
supporting_facts_from_paper: Overall, IS Co favors FM ordering, and the IS-hm state (empty diamond, solid line) is the most energetically favorable state, with energy minimum E_min^(IS-hm)=-350 meV/f.u. at a_pc=3.880 Å (code)
The equilibrium energy and lattice constant of cubic perovskite SrCoO₃ are used as the reference for energy (0 eV) and epitaxial strain ε ≡ a_pc/a₀^(GGA+U)-1, respectively (code)
metadata.explanation: The paper explicitly states that the intermediate-spin half-metallic (IS-hm) state in SrCoO₃ has an energy minimum of E_min^(IS-hm)=-350 meV/f.u. at an in-plane lattice parameter of a_pc=3.880 Å. This quantitative value represents the energy of the IS-hm state relative to the equilibrium energy of cubic perovskite SrCoO₃, which is used as the reference (0 eV). The negative value indicates that the IS-hm state is energetically more favorable than the cubic reference state. The specific in-plane lattice parameter at which this energy minimum occurs corresponds to a specific tensile strain value and provides important information about the structural stability of the IS-hm state.
topics: spin and orbital ordering in transition-metal oxide thin films

claim_text: The intermediate-spin half-metallic state in SrCoO₃ has an energy minimum of -150 meV/f.u. at an in-plane lattice parameter of 3.880 Å

metadata.problem_description: Minimum energy of intermediate-spin half-metallic state in SrCoO₃
supporting_facts_from_paper: Overall, IS Co favors FM ordering, and the IS-hm state (empty diamond, solid line) is the most energetically favorable state, with energy minimum E_min^(IS-hm)=-350 meV/f.u. at a_pc=3.880 Å (code)
The equilibrium energy and lattice constant of cubic perovskite SrCoO₃ are used as the reference for energy (0 eV) and epitaxial strain ε ≡ a_pc/a₀^(GGA+U)-1, respectively (code)
metadata.explanation: This claim is false because the paper specifically reports that the intermediate-spin half-metallic (IS-hm) state in SrCoO₃ has an energy minimum of E_min^(IS-hm)=-350 meV/f.u. at an in-plane lattice parameter of a_pc=3.880 Å, not -150 meV/f.u. as claimed. The claimed value of -150 meV/f.u. is significantly less negative than the actual value reported in the paper, which would imply that the IS-hm state is less energetically favorable relative to the cubic reference state than it actually is. claim_text: The surface of La-doped BaSnO₃ films contains a higher proportion of Ba (20-25%) compared to Sn (13-16%), with oxygen comprising 60-64% of the surface atomic composition.

metadata.problem_description: Surface composition of La-doped BaSnO₃ films
supporting_facts_from_paper: Table 2 presents the elemental composition of the surface of the films obtained from the fit of the XPS spectra. (experiment)
Sample B: Ba 20%, Sn 16%, O 64% (experiment)
Sample C: Ba 25%, Sn 15%, O 60% (experiment)
Sample D: Ba 22%, Sn 16%, O 62% (experiment)
Sample E: Ba 23%, Sn 13%, O 64% (experiment)
The composition is consistent throughout the surface of the various samples, with a larger proportion of Ba compared to Sn. (experiment)
metadata.explanation: Table 2 in the paper provides the surface atomic percentages for the samples measured in XPS. The data clearly shows that across all samples (B, C, D, and E), the surface contains a higher proportion of Ba (ranging from 20% to 25%) compared to Sn (ranging from 13% to 16%), with oxygen comprising 60-64% of the surface atomic composition. The authors note that this composition is consistent throughout the surface of the various samples, with a larger proportion of Ba compared to Sn. This data directly supports the claim about the surface composition of La-doped BaSnO₃ films.

claim_text: The surface of La-doped BaSnO₃ films contains equal proportions of Ba and Sn (approximately 20% each), with oxygen comprising 60% of the surface atomic composition.

metadata.problem_description: Surface composition of La-doped BaSnO₃ films
supporting_facts_from_paper: Table 2 presents the elemental composition of the surface of the films obtained from the fit of the XPS spectra. (experiment)
Sample B: Ba 20%, Sn 16%, O 64% (experiment)
Sample C: Ba 25%, Sn 15%, O 60% (experiment)
Sample D: Ba 22%, Sn 16%, O 62% (experiment)
Sample E: Ba 23%, Sn 13%, O 64% (experiment)
The composition is consistent throughout the surface of the various samples, with a larger proportion of Ba compared to Sn. (experiment)
metadata.explanation: This claim contradicts the data presented in Table 2 of the paper. The XPS measurements clearly show that across all samples, the surface contains a higher proportion of Ba compared to Sn, not equal proportions as claimed. The Ba content ranges from 20% to 25%, while the Sn content ranges from 13% to 16%. The authors explicitly state that the composition is consistent throughout the surface of the various samples, with a larger proportion of Ba compared to Sn. None of the samples show equal proportions of Ba and Sn, making this claim false based on the paper's data.

claim_text: Sb₂Te₃ has the largest in-plane g-factor (19.9) among the Bi₂Se₃ family of compounds

metadata.problem_description: In-plane g-factor of Sb₂Te₃
supporting_facts_from_paper: Among these materials, the Bi₂Te₂Se has the largest out of plane g-factor being 74.7 and the Sb₂Te₃ has the largest in-plane g-factor being 19.9. (theory)

In this work we have recalculated all the parameters of this model together with the g-factors using the first principle method developed previously by our group for all of the Bi₂Se₃ family of compounds listed above, which are summarized in Table.\ref{tb:Bi2Se3_parameters}. (theory)

Due to the large in-plane g-factor and hexagonal warping term in Sb₂Te₃, we take it as an example in the following to show that the intrinsic AHE conductance, including quantized and nearly half-quantized AHE, can all be realized in these materials. (theory)
metadata.explanation: The paper presents first-principle calculations of g-factors for the entire Bi₂Se₃ family of compounds. These calculations explicitly show that Sb₂Te₃ has the largest in-plane g-factor at 19.9, which is why the authors selected it as their primary example for demonstrating quantized and nearly half-quantized anomalous Hall effect.
